fixed

bug.short_desc: NPE in LTW into Swing App (ClassGen.<init>)

when load-time weaving into a Java Swing App (like Java's demo contained in a JDK/demo/jfc called SwingSet2) I receive lots of NPEs form ApsetcJ's LTW. That's the case for the last several versions including the current development build (aspectj-DEVELOPMENT-20060925164058).
When using a pointcut like the following the LTW into Java's SwingSet2 demo fails:
protected pointcut justATest(ActionEvent actionEvent) : execution( public void java.awt.event.ActionListener.actionPerformed(java.awt.event.ActionEvent) ) && args(actionEvent);
This pointcut is used in an around advice which is applied to a Java Swing App running on Java 5. The LTW exception's stack-trace is as follows:

bug.short_desc: CC: Without "Add to source control" when attach a file to Template.

long_desc.thetext:
Environment: CC SCM 6.0.49 EPF 1.0 RC2 0925
Steps: 1. Create a library under CC SCM 2. Create Plug-in, Content package, add all element to source control and check them out 3. Create a template under Guidance 4. Attach a file to template, click 'Save' button 5. Make sure keep checked out is selected 6. Answer 'OK' to add the template XMI file to add to source control
Problem: The attached file and resources folder should be prompted to add to source control too. A workaround is refresh the Navigator view, then the Add to source control dlg will popup.
Refresh newly added attachment so CM plugins got notified to prompt user to add it to source control
Fix is verified on build RC2 0926.

bug.short_desc: [Presentations] 3.3 Presentation: can't reach editor

long_desc.thetext:
3.3 M2
When maximizing a view in the 3.3 Presentation I can't find a handle to directly bring back the editor (area).

Thanks Daniel,
As part of the next revision I'll be adding a 'special' minimized editor stack in order to provide this functionality. It -won't- show the individual editors (since most of the icons would be the same) and it won't attempt to show an editor as a 'fast view'; clicking on either the icon or the 'restore' button will execute the restore behaviour.
Sounds good.
Changing blocking state and marking as fixed in >20070228.
Forget to set the FIXED state. We now support a special trim 'stack' that represents the EditorArea.
Verified in 20070321-0010.

bug.short_desc: Page break lost when printed as PDF in web viewer

long_desc.thetext:
Masterpage was lost when printed as PDF in web viewer
Steps to reproduce: 1.preview attached report in web viewer 2.print as PDF
Expected result: Preview as PDF directly and printed as PDF in web viewer shoud be the same
Actual result: Printed as PDf in web viewer lost master pages while previewed as PDF directly works well
Created an attachment (id=50894) Printed as PDF in web viewer lost master pages
Add several labels and set page break on them,there will be only one page in PDF view
Fixed.
Verified in build 20061008

attachment.desc: Printed as PDF in web viewer lost master pages

bug.short_desc: [Presentations] 3.3 Presentation: allow to customize minimized view stack locations

long_desc.thetext:
3.3 M2
When maximizing in the 3.3 Presentation all other view stacks get minimized to different locations using a heuristic. I can then manually place all of them e.g. to the left side, however they are often placed somewhere else the next time. Besides making the current heuristic predictable and stable the user should be able to tell the view stack where it gets placed.

I like this...let me think about how to do it...the problem is that the stacks aren't 'named' so persistence is somewhat of an issue. I need to find some 'id' that is unique to a particular stack but which also survives restarts (location perhaps?). Any ideas?
Maybe we could compute an ID out of the (restored) location.
This is all part of the new trim layout code (if I can ever get back to it...); the minimized bars are already have ids so what we really need are 'placeholders' for trim that my re-appear...
Changing blocking state and marking as fixed in >20070228.

Verified in 20070321-0010.
Trim locations are persisted across sessions. Once a bar has been placed in a particular spot it'll always to back there.

bug.short_desc: [Presentations] 3.3 Presentation: animation should be in both directions

long_desc.thetext:
3.3 M2
If animation is enabled I can see it when the stacked views get minimized but not when they are restored.

Yeah, I know...;-). The problem is that I can't show a reliably accurate image of the restoring view (and I did have code that just used the icon but it looks terrible). I could snap the image that I animate 'out' with and re-use it for the reverse but I'm guaranteed to get a defect that says it's wrong.
I knew it to be a tricky problem ;-)

Well, if I can't get the performance I need I'll have to revert back to the klunky hollow rects which, while not very cool, work in all cases...
Note that, while it's not symmetric, the current style does the right thing (shows the user where things went) on minimize. On restore they don't need the 'hint' as much since they're going back to something familiar. I'm not saying it's right though...;-).
Changing blocking state....
Ooops, taking this defect back...
Out of cycles...deferring to 3.4.

bug.short_desc: enhancement of birt extension method

long_desc.thetext: Currently if customer want to extend Birt with some feature such as add a new Emitter, it would be a little harder work. It is due to the internal integration mechanism of Birt is not so flexible, and in some case the hard code constant made the extension more complex than just by adding some plug-in or modify some configuration files. For example, when customer want to add a new export type to Birt, a lot core file need to be changed, such as some context class, some constant class, even the layout engine factory class. To make Birt support better extension, it is neccessary to clarify those place where it breaks the plug-in extension method and make them independent with the underlying implementation, and depend on some configuration files instead. Ideally even the export menu or web toolbar js files should be configurable either.
*** Bug 160994 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Fixed, see the sample code in ReportRunner and HTMLReportEmitter.

bug.short_desc: [Workbench] Pull Scripting support into platform

long_desc.thetext:
Both PDE Cheatsheets (Command Composer, see New&Noteworthy for 3.3.M2) and TPTP AutoGUI (see Bug 110337) contain macro/scripting support for Eclipse commands.
While simplistic key recording has been declined as too fragile to solve bug 8519, any of these two might actually be a solution to the problem posed there.
Please consider the two existing solutions and create a platform offering from them.
There are likely more macro/scripting-related bugs that would benefit from such a solution.

Naomi, unless this causes crashes, a loss of data, or a severe memory leak, please lower the severity to Major. How much of a slowdown is this causing (presumably the plugin jar is already cached by the OS)?
I noticed this is already reported in 157098. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=157098
Actually, it's not. That concerns rereading JSP fragments repeatedly, this one's more about poor performance when scanning the XML Catalog-contributed TLDs.

As Nitin said, "Critical" means "crashes, loss of data, severe memory leak". See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/page.cgi?id=fields.html#bug_severity
So, I've changed to major.
Thanks for reporting.

bug.short_desc: No msg about plugin reference is given when importing the library configuration

long_desc.thetext:
Build:epf-composer-1.0-RC2-N20060925-1245-win32
Steps 1.Create a new Library "TestLib"
2.Create a new Method plugin "pluginA" and create some element under "pluginA"
3.Create a new Library Configuration "configA"
4.Check all the element In the Configuration Content Page of configA editor
5.On the exporting library steps,Select the "export one or more method ...", Check the configA and Export it.
6.Create a new Library "TestLib1"
7.Import the exported configA.
Problems-->On the importing progress,No msg is given and there are nothing in the Configuration Content Page of configA editor
Remark: 1.The result of import operation is right,but no msg about the plugin reference is given
2.After step 5,do the following steps
6.Delete configA 7.Import the exported configA
In the Configuration Content Page of configA editor,the reference of pluginA is exist

>>Problems-->On the importing progress,No msg is given and there are nothing >>in the Configuration Content Page of configA editor No message uner the importing progress bar, right? Does the configA editor on the imported lib contain nothing on the config content page, right? what should be the expected contents? all the original selection of packages? right?
>> 2.After step 5,do the following steps >> >> 6.Delete configA >> 7.Import the exported configA are you imported back into the original library?

Looks like you were exporting a configuraiton spec instead of a configuration lib. When the config spec gets imported to a new lib, all its selections are not in the new lib. Therefore, they were correctly removed. If you try importing it into the old lib (after removing the config in the old lib), all selections stay.

(In reply to comment #2) > Looks like you were exporting a configuraiton spec instead of a configuration > lib. When the config spec gets imported to a new lib, all its selections are > not in the new lib. Therefore, they were correctly removed. I think the result is right too,but It should be told that some selections are not in the current lib,That is just my option.
> If you try > importing it into the old lib (after removing the config in the old lib), all > selections stay.
per the developer comment,closed

bug.short_desc: [Release Note] Dynamic attach/detach to the JVMTI Heap Profiler does not work with BEA JRockit versions less than 26.4.0

long_desc.thetext:
A bug in JRockit versions less than R26.4.0 (Java 1.5.0_06) prevents the Martini runtime from redefining java.lang.Object when heap events are enabled or disabled during execution. This cause the attach/detach operation to fail.
The problem was fixed in JRockit R26.4.0 (Java 1.5.0_06).
Asaf FYI : I am seeing the same behavior with Sun JDK 1509 on Linux IA32. The same version of the Sun VM works fine on Windows
Asaf - Is this an issue on JRockit R27?

This issue is relevant for TPTP 4.3 only. In 4.4, the Heap instrumentation was changed. We no longer instrument java.lang.Object, hence we do not need to redefine it when heap events are enabled or disabled. With 4.4, the Heap profiler attach/detach functionality works with all supported JRockit versions (1.5.0_04 and above). Closing the bug.

bug.short_desc: [content assist] Content assist filtering should use case-sensitive relevance

long_desc.thetext:
I20060922-0010
When I type 'SWT.', content assist is automatically activated. When I continue typing to 'SWT.NON', the non-matiching proposals are filtered, but the matching ones are in wrong order: SWT.None SWT.NONE
I would expect that SWT.NONE is before SWT.None, as it is already the case when I invoke content assist after 'SWT.NON'.

I agree that what you request makes sense.
The problem is that up to now we only filter proposals, but never change the ordering as you type. The relevance of a proposal (which is used for sorting, and which already includes match-quality information like case-sensitive matching) is computed only once upfront.
Fixing this will need changes at various places involved with content assist: - do not cache relevance in LazyJavaCompletionProposal - fix various proposal classes that take a relevance in their constructor - fix CompletionProposalPopup#filterProposals()
See also bug 25305.

bug.short_desc: [Wizards] Finish button gets enabled back just before closing the WizardDialog box

long_desc.thetext:
This issue should be valid for all wizards that use WizardDialog as container. More specifically, I report it because I have troubles with the EjbProjectWizard in WTP.
At the end of executing the performFinish() routine the WizardDialog enables back the Next/Back/Finish navigation buttons. There is a time gap between this action and the closure of the wizard box. During this time the user could have the opportunity to hit again the Finish button and do some mess with the newly created project. This situation is hard to reproduce, but I managed to do it couple of times with the EjbProjectWizard.
I digged in the code of the WizardDialog class. The buttons are enabled back in the restoreUIState() method. The callback stacktrace is:
WizardDialog.restoreUIState(Map) line: 810 WizardDialog.stopped(Object) line: 1104 WizardDialog.run(boolean, boolean, IRunnableWithProgress) line: 858 EjbProjectWizard(AddRemoveFacetsWizard).performFinish() line: 285 EjbProjectWizard(NewProjectDataModelFacetWizard).performFinish() line: 307 WizardDialog.finishPressed() line: 680 WizardDialog.buttonPressed(int) line: 355 ...
So, in WizardDialog.finishPressed() the routine calls performFinished() of the embedded wizard and after the method returns, it calls hardClose() to close the wizard box. But what happens in performFinished() is this: 1. WizardDialog.run() is called to execute what the wizard should do. 2. At the end of WizardDialog.run() is called WizardDialog.stopped() and the navigation buttons are now enabled. The wizard box is still visible. 3. The routine exits WizardDialog.run() and is back to performFinish(). Here the embedded wizard may execute additional post finish operations. This may extend significantly the timeframe between the navigation buttons are enabled back and the wizard box is closed.
Pseudographically this could be presented like this:
- WizardDialog.finishPressed() |--- EjbProjectWizard.performFinish() | |--- WizardDialog.run() | | |--- WizardDialog.restoreUIState() ---| | | | | |--- EjbProjectWizard.postPerformFinish() |- GAP | | |--- WizardDialog.hardClose() ---|
As far as I can see the whole "finishedPressed -> run -> performFinish callback -> restoreUIState -> hardClose" routine is under control of the WizardDialog class and after some rearrangement this gap can be closed.

Hello,
Any chance this can be fixed in 3.4?
Greetings

bug.short_desc: Configuring dstore "Running" server is not intuitive

long_desc.thetext:
- Target and host are using different naming for the per user launched dstore-server (using server.pl). The host side should use the term "server" instead of "running" within the launcher properties. - The possibility to configure the server port globally is missing. The launcher properties needs to allow to set the server port in the same way is it is possible for the selection "daemon". It is confusing and very errorneous to have to configure the port on a subsystem for all available subsystems. - The dstore-server on target side should get an option to keep the server alive even if not connected or there should be the possibility to launch the dstore-daemon as non-root (which would be preferable anyway because of security issues).
-----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Testing round 1 installation : Eclipse M20060629-1905 platform-3.2, cdt-3.1.0 RSE install : update-site RSE-complete java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_08-b03 os.name: : Windows XP 5.1, Service Pack 2 ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Unix-dstore targetos : SUSE LINUX 10.1 (i586) targetrelease: Linux osgiliath 2.6.16.21-0.21-default #1 Tue Aug 29 16:42:05 UTC 2006 i686 athlon i386 GNU/Linux targetvm : Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_07-b03, mixed mode, sharing) ------------------------------------------------

Just to clarify: (1) In the New Connection Wizard, Launcher Properties, "Running" type should be named "Running Server" or "Server" (2) In the New Connection Wizard, Launcher Properties for the Running Server Type, the "Port" property is missing (This is bug 142969) (3) server.pl should have an option to keep it alive (3a) timeout = infinite should be the default option (3b) dont quit after disconnect (4) daemon.pl should be able to run as non-root --> In that case it would allow connection only for the same user who started the daemon; all other users would get "permission denied" (5) The REXEC server launcher is not useful any more since few hosts have REXEC enabled. An ssh server launcher should be provided instead, potentially with tunnelling the dstore connection through ssh (this is bug 142971)
Would you agree with this re-wording?
Dave M - sending this to you for your opinion on the suggested changes.

(1) I agree that it should say "Running Server" instead of "Running". (2) this is a larger issue and should be addressed with bug 142969 (3) a. I'm not sure whether infinate should be the default as it raises security concerns. b. Why would you not want to quit after disconnect? (4) I suppose that would be reasonable to have a single user daemon. (5) bug 142971

bug.short_desc: Target shell does not show any output

long_desc.thetext:
- Created an empty directory on the target - Launch shell for that empty directory - Executing "ls" --> no output, no matter how often the command is entered. Only "ls -a" does bring output.
The target shell needs to show any command executing on target independ if or if not the command returns an output.

bug.short_desc: Make "Show in table" action label more context sensitive

long_desc.thetext:
The "Show in table" action should have context sensitive label. If selecting a directory, the should be labeled "Show directory content" in example. "Show in table" is not intuitive for the user to understand what the purpose of such action might be.
-----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Testing round 1 installation : Eclipse M20060629-1905 platform-3.2, cdt-3.1.0 RSE install : update-site RSE-complete java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_08-b03 os.name: : Windows XP 5.1, Service Pack 2 ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Unix-ssh (dstore-processes) targetos : SUSE LINUX 10.1 (i586) targetrelease: Linux osgiliath 2.6.16.21-0.21-default #1 Tue Aug 29 16:42:05 UTC 2006 i686 athlon i386 GNU/Linux targetvm : Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_07-b03, mixed mode, sharing) ------------------------------------------------

I'm not so sure this is a good idea. Resources can be anything, not necessarily files or directories - it depends on the subsystem. Tailoring the menu based on the resource would require contributors to supply action names for this action.

Hm, I agree.
What did confuse me as well, though, was that choosing "Show in Table" on a single file or an empty directory does not yield useful results at all. In fact, not the selected resource is shown in the table but the contents of the resource.
But I must admit that I have no good idea for solving this. I guess that users will have to adjust to the way it is.

Dave, what should we do about this bug? I'm not sure we want to change the names depending on context.
As for leaf nodes (e.g. files), I believe we no longer show the action for them.
I think we should leave it as "Show in table". I think it's better to keep the name consistent, and now the action shouldn't show for leaves anyway. Do you think this is closable?
Ok, let's close it as WONTFIX.

bug.short_desc: Allow filters to affect folders as well as files

long_desc.thetext:
- created a folder /folk/uwe/tmp/test - created a new filter "MyFilterTest" for the folder /folk/uwe/tmp, subset by file name, file name filter "*" --> the whole content of /folk/uwe/tmp is obviously shown - tried to limit the filter later by setting file name filter to "test" --> still the whole content is shown even after a refresh. The expected outcome would be that only the folder named "test" will remain.
-----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Testing round 1 installation : Eclipse M20060629-1905 platform-3.2, cdt-3.1.0 RSE install : update-site RSE-complete java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_08-b03 os.name: : Windows XP 5.1, Service Pack 2 ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Unix-ssh (dstore-processes) targetos : SUSE LINUX 10.1 (i586) targetrelease: Linux osgiliath 2.6.16.21-0.21-default #1 Tue Aug 29 16:42:05 UTC 2006 i686 athlon i386 GNU/Linux targetvm : Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_07-b03, mixed mode, sharing) ------------------------------------------------

This is as expected. Folders are currently not subject to the filtering criteria. This allows a couple of things (1) a folder created under a filter will always show up and (2) allows drill down into all folders looking for files that match a pattern. The behavior is similar to findfile <root-path> -name "<pattern>".
Clearly, however, we need to beef up the criteria for filters to be able to filter things besides files. I'm going to change this to and "enhancement" and move it to after R1.
Changing the title to reflect the request. Previous title was "Filter by file name / file type has no effect".

bug.short_desc: The overlay used to visualize symbolic links is not Eclipse like

long_desc.thetext:
Folder or file which are symbolic links on the target, gets a hard to identify overlay on the top left corner. It would be better to understand if symbolic links would use the same overlay at the lower right corner as Eclipse is using for linked resources.
-----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Testing round 1 installation : Eclipse M20060629-1905 platform-3.2, cdt-3.1.0 RSE install : update-site RSE-complete java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_08-b03 os.name: : Windows XP 5.1, Service Pack 2 ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Unix-ssh (dstore-processes) targetos : SUSE LINUX 10.1 (i586) targetrelease: Linux osgiliath 2.6.16.21-0.21-default #1 Tue Aug 29 16:42:05 UTC 2006 i686 athlon i386 GNU/Linux targetvm : Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_07-b03, mixed mode, sharing) ------------------------------------------------

Do we agree that we want this changed? - Symbolic links are something different than Eclipse Linked Resources, although there is a proposal to treat them the same (bug 44107). Also, Eclipse Linked Resources and RSE Symbolic Links can not appear in the same view, so it may be OK to provide the same icon for them. Or was there a specific reason for using a different overlay than the standard Eclipse one?
Uwe, if we agree we want this you could probably best find a proper icon.

(In reply to comment #1) > Also, Eclipse Linked Resources and RSE Symbolic Links can not appear in the > same view, so it may be OK to provide the same icon for them. Or was there a > specific reason for using a different overlay than the standard Eclipse one?
I think the choice of overlay icon was somewhat arbitrary - if the standard eclipse one conveys the same idea, I'm okay with using it. The location of top left corner was chosen arbitrarily too in order to be distinct from the classification type icon used in the bottom left corner.
Waiting for whether the Platform comes up with a different icon for symbolic links, via bug 44107 and bug 209190.

bug.short_desc: [EFS] Make workspace itself EFS-capable

long_desc.thetext:
You can store projects/folders/files on remote file systems with the EFS now. To provide a bit more, it should be possible to store the workspace itself (with it's metadata) on the remote file system. I talked to John about this and he's right: It would be a very hard task. This issue also come up in bug 106176, comment #41:
> You should be aware that were are not currently considering redirecting file > system access for arbitrary Eclipse metadata (things in the workspace/.metadata > directory). This would be *much* more ambitious than our current scope.
In any case, i think it's an enhancement which should be adressed - and therefore this enhancement request. Mark it as helpwanted, do it yourself or close it as WONTFIX ;) But in my eyes, this is a worth to be a request :)

This would be an enhancement request against the platform runtime rather than resources. All RCP plugins would need to move if this was changed. I'm actually going to mark this as a duplicate of an existing bug I found relating to non-local workspaces. I think the correct phrasing of the enhancement is that support for non-local workspaces be added - whether this is addressed using EFS or some other abstraction is an implementation detail.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 140596 ***

bug.short_desc: Make click on "current task" in Task List

long_desc.thetext:
When I have an active task the "line" in Task List which shows:
Find: <no active task>
changes to
Find: <some task>
I would like to be able to click <some task> and then have it open the actual task. It would save one step since I now have to double-click on the active task in the task list to open it.

Currently behavior si that the task will be selected in the Task List (takes two clicks if there is a "Find:" filter on). But now that we do not do a round trip to the server for repository tasks maybe it does make sense to simply open it, and I believe that this is the common case for me too.
Rob, thoughts?
If you'd have a regular dropdown as I suggested instead of "<-" button, one could just click on that button to open task (e.g. when it is active)...

Done.
Eugene: the Back button's single click to go back to the previous task being worked on facilitates multi-tasking by making it a single easy click, e.g. when temporarily interrupted by a task, then one more click to get back.
Created an attachment (id=52292) mylar/context/zip
Oops, wrong assignment.
Done.

bug.short_desc: Jtopen jdbc driver and birt --> Can't restrict DB

long_desc.thetext:
While using Jopen jdbc driver, I noticed you can restrict the query to a list of libraries using the libraries parameter.
The problem is that when you create a dataset, BIRT retreives the whole list of libraries on the I Series and not only the one you sepcified. We're talking about hundreds of libs and taht atkes a while.
While running the report, the restriction works just fine. It's annoying to wait for 5 to 10mn to ba able to create or modify a dataset...
Thanx for your input
Please try window->preference->reportdesign->dataset editor->jdbc dataset to set up the initial number of schema/tables to be fetched.I think this may what you want.

Hi,
I've tried the following : - fetch 1 table - fetch 1 schema
The display is right (it fetchs all right) but it still takes a while to load the dataset editor (around 5 mn on a wired network). I guess even with the fetch parameter, the soft loads the entire scheme and then filters...
Thnx
We will investigate this issue. Thanks.

What DBMS did you use? i think most of these DBMSs have their client software, can you try it and see how fast it will be? and how many Schemas did u have when you made this test? and finally, can you try some other drivers?
By the way, what was the birt version you used?

OK, I'm using an iSeries and I'm connecting to a DB2 database.
I've tried with a simple ODBC driver and it works fine. (You can restrict to a single DB in the ODBC control panel). The problem is that I'm trying to integrate BIRT to an application and the jtopen driver allows you to specify a database with a parameter. This is the part where I need to use jtopen...
I'm using BIRT 2.1.0.
Thanx for the input ...
Keep up the good work.

Hi,
So I get the basic undertanding of your situation:You want to connect to a very large database with tons of schemas in a wired network. The database is so large that an iteration of all its schemas would be very time consuming.You need certain mechanism to limit the number of schema names fetch from database to speed the creation of data set (currently we fetch all schema names). The bottleneck would be the fetching of all available schema names (which is typically very short in time under ordinary condition).
So maybe what you want is that Birt do not fetch an schema in data set editor at all. Then you can use filter to fetch the schema that you exactlly needed during design time?
Am I put the situation right?
Thanks. Lin

A check box was added in DataSetPreferencePage to indicate whether all the schemas should be prefetched or not, the default value is YES. If the check box is unchecked, no schema will be fetched from database when SQLDataSetEditor is activated, users can specify the schema name in the combo list or get all the schemas by filtering, in order to speed up the display of SQLDataSetEditor when there are lots of schemas and tables in the database, or when the network condition is crappy.

Nice work guys... That sould do the trick... Thanks
P.S : In which version of BIRT did you add that checkbox ?

In latest BIRT nightly build or the build 2.2.0 M2 which will be released this week you can find the check box:)
Thanks. Lin

bug.short_desc: [DiagramEditor] DiagramInputDocumentProvider can't be used as IDiagramDocumentProvider

long_desc.thetext: DiagramInputDocumentProvider#createInputWithEditingDomain() wraps IDiagramEditorInput into EditorInputProxy. Returned value (@see DiagramDocumentEditor#doSetInput:421) is passed to IDocumentProvider#connect and eventually to DiagramInputDocumentProvider#createElementInfo and #createDocument(). Both methods assume input to be instanceof IDiagramEditorInput, which is not the case with EditorInputProxy. Hence, using DiagramInputDocumentProvider within diagram editor not possible.

Another issue: DiagramInputDocumentProvider#updateCache() adapts EditorInputProxy to IStrorage, while DiagramEditorInput#getAdapter() understands IFile requests only. Thus, DiagramResourceInfo.fIsModifiable is never true

Created an attachment (id=50997) Rough idea of the fix for IStorage/IFile
The patch makes DiagramEditorInput adaptable to IResource as well, which may cause some side effects.
Is this something we can do in 2.0? Is it blocking anything in the 1.0 stream?
It doesn't block anything in 1.0.x stream. 2.0 certainly is ok.
Moving to the next release, GMF 2.1.

attachment.desc: Rough idea of the fix for IStorage/IFile

bug.short_desc: Index fails miserably when memory mapped files are unavailable

long_desc.thetext: When we fail to get a memory mapped file, a wack load of NPEs and bad behavior occur. We need to be more robust when that happens.
The last second drive for CDT 3.1.1 continues...

Fixed in 3.1.1. No plan to put this into head. Now when the memory map operation fails for a PDOM database chunk, the section of the file is read into a direct byte buffer which is then saved after the write lock is released on the PDOM. Hopefully, no one will need to encounter this functionality...

bug.short_desc: Canvas#scroll forces an update - any way around this besides setRedraw(false)

long_desc.thetext:
In bug 117507 and bug 121049 we have explored ways to gain performance by not so much using Control#setRedraw(on/off) brackets around operations in editors. In many places, we have successfully gotten rid of setRedraw calls, however, in others we still need it to avoid flickering.
One problem is that sometimes an operation will trigger the styled text to scroll, which in turn flushes the paint queue by calling update(). While I understand this is needed for how Canvas#scroll() works, I would like to know if there is any other way besides calling setRedraw() to avoid having the paintQueue "prematurely" flushed.
An example of this is the "Organize Imports" action in the Java editor: it inserts some text out-of-context (i.e. not where the caret is). Since we want to keep the caret line visually stable, we call StyledText#setTopPixel() after the operation. If we wrap this into a setRedraw() bracket, everything is fine (besides some scrollbar flashing on GTK). If we leave out the setRedraw, we first see the text changes come in and then the content is scrolled to keep the caret line stable.

The problem is that if there is outstanding damage for a control, the control must be forced to paint before the bits can be grabbed from the screen and copied to a new location. If this is not done, then the wrong bits will get copied.
Some platforms support scrolling the outstanding damage so that when the paint event is finally delivered, it will draw on top of the incorrect bits that were copied and the end result will be cheese free. We have investigated supporting this in the past and have run away due to lack of time. Maybe it's time to investigate it again.

> An example of this is the "Organize Imports" action ...
Tom, can you code up a simple snippet that captures the problem you are having and see what we can do about it?

Created an attachment (id=50917) StyledTextRedraw.java
Snippet showing the behavior. It is not necessarily a scroll event that forces the paint queue to flush, but in this case simply a content modification.
The two StyledText areas both have a selection (line 6). When the button is pressed, some "imports" are added to the content (at line 3). We want to keep the selection visually stable, hence set the topIndex such that the linePixel of the selected line is kept constant.
In the version without setRedraw, one can see a flicker as the content is updated.
Whe does replaceTextRange() scroll? It shouldn't.
Can't we just fix that?

> Whe does replaceTextRange() scroll? If you are adding a new style range that has bigger font, causing the height of the current line to increase. All the lines bellow current line needs to scroll (or redraw). The same goes if you are deleting the tallest font of the line, causing the line the shrink.
Is is scrolling when it should not ?

I tested the StyledTextRedraw. Here is what I think: The application "knows" it will scroll back to the exact same position after modifing the content. StyledText doesn't know that, when the content changes it *needs* to scroll the content. Before scrolling it needs to validade the area (as Steve has already explained).
I think in this case it is okay to use "setRedraw()". It won't flash, the widget is double buffer ;-)
OK, so SWT's (final ;-) advice is to close this PR and leave the setRedraw(...) in cases where the changes are triggered by the content?
Yes, IMO you can leave the setRedraw in this case.

The scenario is making two changes to the widget, and the intermediate state should not be visible to the user. Well ... OK, the second change also is forcing the user to see that intermediate state, but other things could happen to cause a Control to paint, so turning off painting is probably valid.
Also, it seems like there's no harm in the current solution? WORKSFORME?
Not yet. I still believe that the widget should not scroll.
FH, can you take a look at this? Control.setRedraw() doesn't do much on Windows but it causes trouble on other platforms that don't support it well.
Will this be investigated for 3.3?
Felipe, I still believe that it should not scroll.
Dani, I can change the code as Steve wants: StyledText will not scroll when the change happens above the topIndex. It means you can remove the setTopPixel you have in your code.

Fixed in HEAD > 20070130
Dani: let me know if the new behavior causes problem for you.

Just for completeness: there will still be places where the editor does not get around setTopPixel calls. Example:
- the import is added above the caret line, but still within the visible area of StyledText -> the area below the added import is scrolled down. - the goal of the editor is to keep the caret line visually stable, so the entire editor is scrolled upwards by the number of lines inserted.
I guess it is ok to use setRedraw in these cases, I don't see anything StyledText could do to help here.

>in response to #17:
Yes, you are right!

bug.short_desc: [Intro] missing icon on the standby page of the swt welcome theme purple mesh

long_desc.thetext: On Solaris (or linux w/o Mozilla) the intro standby page displays no icon (well, the red square) for the "Go to Workbench" action at the bottom. Suggested fix: An entry in "org.eclipse.ui.intro.universal/themes/purpleMesh/swt/standby.properties": standby.action-links.workbench.link-icon = ../graphics/icons/ctool/wb48.gif
Could it be that the new .gif loading code fails on this gif?
I don't see this, though I'm probably doing something differently since I'm not sure what the standby page is. Are there steps to get to it from the Welcome main page?
To reach the standby page, open the Into (Help->Welcome) and double-click the "Welcome" tab (above the text "Welcome to Eclipse 3.2")

Ok, I see this now, it happens in 3.2 and in 3.3M2.
Since it happens in 3.2 it's not related to the new image loading code that was introduced in 3.2.1. The suggested fix implies that there's just a properties entry missing for this image, so moving report to UI. If it turns out to be an image loading problem then please return to SWT.
Fixed by adding new entries to standby.properties

bug.short_desc: Direct print/ Silent print

long_desc.thetext:
I need a parameter in the URL so it is possible to sent documents directly to a printer without user interaction. For example an additional format : __format=print should make this happen.
Example : http://server01:8080/birt-viewer/run?__report=Report/testreport.rptdesign&__format=print
It is possible to have better alternative's. I'm open for better solutions. And of course, I'm available for testing this.
There is a project proposal in 2.2 to support postscript output format. Also need to enhance engine API to allow application to set printer and print setting for the selected printer.
1. engine should implement a postscript emitter. 2. viewer should call the printer setup and send the postscript files to the printer.
once engine done, please implement this for viewer side.

Add a new icon : "Print report on the server" in Web Viewer toolbar. Currently, we only support print postscript file. User should set up a printer which supports postscript stream.
In print report dialog, user can select printer and other print settings. Of course, user also can specify these settins in URL. ============================================================================= __page : Numeric Specify which page will be output. It should be a number.
__pagerange : String separated with comma. Specify the output page range. For example : 1-4 or 1, 3, 6.If blank, default to all pages.
__printer : String Specify the selected printer name.
__printer_copies : Numeric Specify copies attribute for printer
__printer_collate : true of false (Default to false) Specify collate attribute for printer
__printer_duplex : DUPLEX_SIMPLEX:0,DUPLEX_HORIZONTAL:1,DUPLEX_VERTICAL:2 Specify duplex attribute for printer
__printer_mode : MODE_MONOCHROME:0,MODE_COLOR:1 Specify color mode attribute for printer
__printer_pagesize: String Specify media size name attribute for printer
__action : String Specify action name. Currently, use "print" to indicate printing report on the server ===============================================================================
If disable print function, please set BIRT_VIEWER_PRINT_SERVERSIDE to OFF value in web.xml.Default value is ON, please check it.

bug.short_desc: Plugin types discrimination

long_desc.thetext:
Hello, I would suggest another means of managing the plugins in the platform. The goal is to be able to manage several kinds of plugins sets from a single eclipse installation... For instance, I've a basic eclipse installation with JDT+GEF+EMF+... Moreover I would like to have a set of plugins like Omondo, Fireant, ... and another one with SWT designer, Groovy, ... Up to now I've to put all these plugins together under the plugins directory , so I can't discriminate my usages. The solution today is to duplicate the eclipse installation to perform what I want... The idea is to have the ability to have several plugins repositories like : * commonPlugins : the plugins common to every eclipse sets * plugins1 : set of plugins * plugins2 : set of plugins * ...
Once these created, when we launch eclipse, the tool ask the user to choose/create a launch configuration. In this configuration, we have to select : * the workspace we use * the external plugin set directory
the common plugin directory is implicit.
regards Xavier

bug.short_desc: Device Manager will only locate UEI SDKs

long_desc.thetext: The device manager has been modified to only select UEI devices. This prevents others from adding SDKs into the mix and allowing these to be selected. This severly limits the usefullness of the tools. New devices should not need to create their own Device managers.

Created an attachment (id=52052) Code to add a dialog when there is more then one provider match
I am providing a patch that will add a dialog when there is more then one match for the DeviceProvider. We should also eliminate the org.eclipse.mtj.extension.dpp.nokia provider from the product release if all functionality for these devices is also in org.eclipse.mtj.extension.dpp.uei. If there are no objections, I will commit this patch October 17th.
Created an attachment (id=52054) Example of dialog with a Nokia device responding to Generic UEI and Nokia specific

We will also have to evaluate this change when we add a generic device in the future. We can add a checkbox on the dialog that performs the search to allow the user to manually configure instead of doing a search.

Initial tests look good - if I try my runtime I get my provider and generic, as expected.
I also get Nokia as a platform provider however. I think the Nokia Platform provider needs to be a little more selective and not return a "match" if it isn't a realy Nokia platform.
For example, If I add WTK, I get a list of the Nokia provider and Generic UEI. I would only expect Generic UEI. It's confusing to get a match for Nokia with WTK.
It might be a matter of changing the Nokia platform provider to check the UEI properties (or some other files) and return null if it doesn't match a Nokia SDK.

Created an attachment (id=52091) Adding WTK results in Nokia Platform Provider selection
Attachment shows adding a WTK 22 platform. Nokia Platform Provider is offered as an option - the resulting Device Platform shows J2ME Wireless Toolkit 2.2 - seems confusing

As stated in my earlier mails, the automatization on importing the mobile SDK /Device platforms is very difficult, if there is no common communication, nor common SDK detection.
As the current case is with rel. 0.7 that there are only UEI based SDK / dpp providers available and the current bugs are planned to be fixed. Currently there are no Non-Uei SDKs / providers available, nor documented and there are no architectural discussion around that. (until in now, with in these bugs). I would propose that there are no other modifications to the dpp-providers than the component owner makes, cause there is ongoing development with these components without having committed yet to cvs.
All changes should be first agreed in architectural layer before committing.
Now we should focus in MTJ to stabilize the rel. 0.7 release with it's agreed content.
So, how to add more different dpp providers to MTJ, could to follow the current architecture. E.g. There could be an automatic and a manual mode for the actual device platform provider. With manual mode the developer could select e.g. the non-uei provider, if needed. But, this needs more planning, coding, testing, etc. and I would wait until we have fixed the current UEI based SDK / DPP cases.

We need a solution to this problem before we release. This is a show stopper. We need to be able to handle more then this single provider, and this support was removed before M2. Code needs to be implemented before release that allows this to work in some way. This is one suggestion for a fix for release that works. We can not leave this problem as is, and declare our code complete because we are missing a critical function for our users.

The current RC1 release has a new feature that in the DeviceManagement gathers all DevicePlatform import providers, adds them to an array and moves the Generic UEI provider to last one. When the SDK folder has been selected the provider array is processed and the providers try to create an DevicePlatform from 4 folders below the selected root folder. In the provider array can be also non-MTJ providers (the detection is done based on the extension point contribution).
So, now MTJ supports also other mobile SDK providers (even those that are not implemented in MTJ).
The current solution has some smaller risks, but overall it provides a way to go further and improve it in later releases.
-Arto
This is not a perfect solution, but it is working.

Adding WTK results in Nokia Platform Provider selection

bug.short_desc: Connect/Enter Password dialog does not allow storing an empty password

long_desc.thetext:
Create a Windows-dstore connection. Expand the Files/Drives filter. An "Enter password" dialog is shown.
There is no option to tick the "save password" box although an empty password is allowed. Because of this, when I disconnect and reconnect, I'll always get the user/password dialog on the implicit connect, which is cumbersome.
Workaround: Enter some dummy password e.g. "a" and store it.
This bug is also relevant for ssh connections, where an empty password makes sense if user uses a private key with or without passphrase instead of the password.
-----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Testing round 1 installation : eclipse-platform-3.3M2 (I20060922-0010) RSE install : download rse-runtime-core,dstore,local,ssh java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_06-b05 os.name: : Red Hat Enterprise Linux WS release 4 (Nahant Update 3) ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Dstore-windows, Linux-local, Ssh targetos : Windows XP SP2, and others targetuname : Windows targetvm : Sun 1.5.0_08-b03 ------------------------------------------------

Found another workaround:
In the password field, enter a space (this enables the "save password" box), then delete it again ("save password" remains enabled). So it looks like the state handling of the save password box is not updated correctly.
With this workaround, the empty password is stored correctly. So, the fix for this should be really simple.

We now allow an empty string password to be saved - typically used for SSH.
The login prompt shouldn't even be showing for Windows connections since we do not validate either the name or the userid for dstore connections. We now suppress the showing of this prompt entirely so the saving of an empty password is now moot.

bug.short_desc: EclipsePreferences getBoolean should return true for "1"

long_desc.thetext: The EclipsePreferences method only returns true if the value is the string "true". However, when talking booleans, a value of "1" should also return true.

IEclipsePreferences extends the Preferences API as defined by OSGi. The spec for this states that the only valid values are the strings "true" and "false".
We should return "false" for values of "1" in order to remain consistent with this spec.
You can request an enhancement to the OSGi Preferences Service spec by filing a bug at http://bundles.osgi.org/bugzilla/

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] Win x64 version of 3.2 doesn't seem to like to display filter widgets

long_desc.thetext:
I first ran into this trying to run java applications in a new installation of v3.2 on a new WinXP x64 machine. What I noticed was that the Run dialog didn't display any launch configurations. Then, when reading the "What's New" section of the documentation, I discovered that none of the launch filters nor application types displayed on the preferences pages ("Run/Debug > Launching > Launch Configurations" or "Run/Debug > Perspectives"). Finally (and this is what made me think it might be more of a general issue), I noticed that "General > Appearance > Colors and Fonts" doesn't display the expected filter widget.
The only inconsistent part of this (that I've noticed, at least) is that the main preferences tree, which appears to be a filter widget, *does* display correctly.
I realize that the x64 version of Windows XP isn't officially supported, but has anyone else experienced this? Has anyone figured out a workaround?
Thanks in advance,
John Glover

Steve, since we don't have a WinXP x64 machine in the lab, can SWT check on their WinXP x64 machine that filtered trees are displaying (or not)? Examples are in the Show View dialog, Import, Export and New Wizards (wizard selection page), Preferences dialog, and the (new) Keys preference page.
The FilteredTree class (in the ui.workbench plugin) is a subclass of a Composite containing a text and a tree viewer. The only potential problem I can see is that setBackground() is overridden and most filtered tree implementations have to call something like: setBackground(parent.getDisplay().getSystemColor(SWT.COLOR_WIDGET_BACKGROUND)) in order to set the background color to match the rest of the composite.

Hold up - is this a dup of bug 136486? John, can you try resizing the sash (in the Run configurations dialog), as suggested in bug 136486#c8? Does resizing the dialog itself (for the show view and wizard dialogs) offer a workaround for those cases?

Yes, it does appear to behave in the same was as bug 136486. I had tried resizing the dialog as a whole (from the outside edges) which didn't affect it, but resizing the inner window (resulting in resizing the filter control itself) makes the entries show up.
I don't recall seeing that entry when I searched for similar behavior, but it looks like this one should most likely be marked as a duplicate. (I would be happy to mark it as a duplicate, but since I'm new around here, I don't want to step on anyone's toes...)
Thanks for your help!

I guess that means there is a workaround for the preferences dialog and the run configurations dialog, but not for the show view or wizard dialogs (or any other case where fitered tree is used where there is no sash).

bug.short_desc: Add accessible selection

long_desc.thetext:
The native widgets on Linux (RHEL 5 or FC5) that have selectable children already expose the Selection interface. (See http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/atk/AtkSelection.html.) Custom widget authors (including Draw2d and GMF authors) need the ability to expose selected children to native assitive technologies (like a screen reader). I suggest adding a new AccessibleSelectionListener to the org.eclipse.swt.accessibility package to allow custom widget authors the ability to expose the rich AtkSelection interface.
Note that this selection is distinguished from text selection by exposing selection of (usually lighweight) accessible children instead of a subset of the object's content.
The mechanism to implement this functionality on Windows will be added soon.

Just curious - the current API allows the parent object to send accessible.selectionChanged() ...which of course leaves it up to the screen reader to find out what changed (because no details are given). I could see that this might be inefficient. The question is: is there any information that the screen reader just cannot get in this scenario?

(In reply to comment #1) Yes, this is inefficient. But on Windows it may not matter since the screen reader runs in-process. The trade-off is between always including the changed information versus storing old and comparing to new selection only when needed. Since the screen reader may ignore the event, or only be interested in the current selection, there is no compelling argument to include the change information on Windows.
But on Linux the screen reader is required to run in another process. And as a result, ATK accessibility events include old and new values to minimize the number of cross-process calls.
When the event includes no change information, the screen reader has to store "old state" information for comparison to the "current state" to determine the nature of a change. Otherwise the screen reader has no way of determining (and presenting) a non-focused (programmatic) change of selection.
Thanks, Larry. Next question - forgive me for not being up-to-date on Linux screen readers - is there a plan in progress to allow screen readers and other AT's to run in-process? Again, just curious.

(In reply to comment #3) There is no plan to allow Linux screen readers to run in-process. But there is a plan to require Windows screen readers to run out of process. Microsoft calls it "managed applications" made accessible through UI Automation. Requiring the AT to run out of process is the future on all platforms due to security requirements.
Thanks, Larry. Carolyn

bug.short_desc: Add accessible action

long_desc.thetext:
The native widgets on Linux (RHEL 5 or FC5) that expose user actions already expose the Action interface. (See http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/atk/AtkImage.html.) And the current AccessibleControlListener does provide a getDefaultAction() method that allows customization of the (string) name exposed for a single action. But more is needed by custom widget authors (including Draw2d and GMF authors) to expose more than a single action, and to customize the behavior of those actions.
I suggest adding a new AccessibleActionListener to the org.eclipse.swt.accessibility package to allow custom widget authors the ability to expose the rich AtkAction interface. The existing AccessibleControlListener should add a method that allows customization of the "default action" behavior. And it should be coordinated with the new ActionListener interface such that the default action will be the first (of the possible multiple) action exposed through the ActionListener.
The mechanism to implement this functionality on Windows will be added soon.

bug.short_desc: execution environment causing bundles to be not resolved

long_desc.thetext:
in 3.3 m2
Steps - clean workspace - set the target platform to some bogus path (i.e., ensure you have no target platform) - check out HEAD of org.eclipse.orbit/javax.servlet and javax.servlet.jsp from the Tools repo (dev.eclipse.org/cvsroot/tools) - replace javax.servlet with the v2_3 branch - replace javax.servlet.jsp with the v1_2 branch - notice that there are no errors/warnings on either project - open javax.servlet manifest and add J2SE-1.3 as an Execution Environtment and save - Notice that you (likely) now have a warning that the JRE on the build path is not an exact match to that set in the EE. (good warning, not a problem) - Notice also (likely) that the JSP project did not get rebuilt. - do a clean build of both projects - Notice now that there are two errors on the JSP project saying, in essence, that the javax.servlet project is not resolved. - there are no errors on the javax.servlet project and no indication of what the problem might be. - remove the J2SE-1.3 EE from javax.serlvet and rebuild, the errors go away - Notice that the warning on javax.servlet has NOT disappeared. When the EE was removed, the JRE classpath container was still left as J2SE-1.3 (which does not exist in my environment)
Several issues here - the dependent project is not built when the prereq changed - javax.servlet should be resolved in this case - there is no indication of what the problem is or how to fix it - the JRE classpath container is not cleared when all EEs are removed from the manifest
This is a rather significant problem for the Orbit project as we need to set the EEs for all our new bundles and want to ensure that that community gets in the habit from the very beginning.

Upon some investigation, the unresolved errors come from an invalid target platform. PDE looks for org.eclipse.osgi to find the execution environment profiles. When setting the target platform to a bogus location, the profiles are not found and the system packages for each profile cannot be calculated. The result is the resolver state does not know about any of the execution environments and therefore flags them as unresolved.
To correct this problem, set your target platform to one that contains only org.eclipse.osgi. This way the execution env. are available and projects can use them to resolve.
I will continue to investigate and see if we might be able to do some things different to handle this case.

good answer. Thanks. It seems reasonable that someone developing a bundle would have OSGi in their target. Some thoughts on going forward...
- If one is to use PDE to bundles for frameworks other than Equinox, the profile files would have to come from somewhere else.
- Similarly, people doing normal java development but using PDE as a module development environment would benefit from managing their EE but would not typicaly have org.eclispe.osgi in their target.
Perhaps the profiles should be contributed via an extension piont in the same way as the EE definitions are? Or, there has been some talk about defining a generic VM descriptoin file. Perhaps this information can go in there?
Dropping the severity since we have a reasonable workaround.

To address some of the other original problems:
- the dependent project is not built when the prereq changed Trying to trigger a builder upon receiving the change notification results in a ResourceException, stating the workspace is locked for modifications. We might be able to get around this, but it requires more investigation.
- there is no indication of what the problem is or how to fix it You are right, PDE does not show the reason a bundle is unresolved.
- the JRE classpath container is not cleared when all EEs are removed from the manifest PDE does not change the JDT classpath container except when the user specifically specifies (PDE > Update Classpath). Wassim might have an opinion on this item.
Reassigning to inbox since this involves some desing work to figure out how to make EEs work better.

I thought you were getting the EE profiles from the running tooling environment that PDE is currently running in, not the target. PDE tooling is always running ontop of Equinox which contains the profiles. At the very least you could fall back to these profiles, right?

I think we need to revisit how we do execution env. profiles.
Not sure if reading from the running tooling instance is correct. This might cause problems if the target platform is set to something that does not support any/all the profiles found in the tooling instance. We wouldn't want our users to develop against profiles which won't be included when they launch a runtime workbench.
I want to get Wassim's 2 cents on this since he always has an opinion on everything.

In addition to providing an extension point to allow execution environment profiles to be added, I think the mechanism that the PDE uses to select an execution environment might need to be revisited. If the user does not set the execution environment in the manifest, PDE seems to always select the "highest" execution environment that is present in the osgi bundle, which may or may not be valid for the particular jre that is set as the default jre in the eclipse preferences.

A target definition does not define the execution environment does it? You can self-host an instance (or target) against the VM of your choice I don't see a problem with allowing developers to develop against an EE that may not be used when they launch Eclipse. The issue is if a bundle developer specifies a required EE then we should give them proper resolution errors if the EE is not available at development time as well as at runtime.
At tool-time we want to allow different bundles to be compiled against different EEs. If we limit the EE to only the VM you use to launch the target then this will not be possible.

(In reply to comment #3) > - there is no indication of what the problem is or how to fix it > You are right, PDE does not show the reason a bundle is unresolved.
I opened bug 159066 for this as it seems to be a separate and reasonably significant item.
As for where the profiles should come from... Likely we should look in the target first then in the dev configuration. Having an extension point still feels good since the set is most definitely open ended and we need a way of adding profiles. There may be something already in the extension point used to add JRE types and EEs.

bug.short_desc: Performance improvement of Grid

long_desc.thetext:
Anton, can you attach a patch? With a patch I can do a diff and easier see whats changed.
The change you've made to Grid.newItem doesn't take into account the possibility that a user may turn on and off the row header. I can't easily tell what changes were made to the constructors. I'm not sure what adding Grid.lastIndexOf gains us.

I have attached the patch.
About Grid.newItem changes. I agree that it does take into account the possibility to not turn on and off the row header. But it actually gives significant performance boost. As a solution, Grid could calculate row header when user turns on this feature.
lastIndexOf is also significant performance improvement in case of deep hierarchy and many elements.
I actually did performance investigation using TPTP and lots of data (100000 items and 1000 top items with 10 levels on each item). I can provide you with this data. It clearly shows these 3 hotspots which are very significant.

You can create patches in the unified/Eclipse format by using the Team - Create Patch menu in Eclipse. These patches can then be imported and compared easily in Eclipse.
I would like to see any info you have. I have previously done some performance work and did have code to minimize the row header width calc, but it was removed as it interfered with other feature work.
I will apply your patch as long as its complete (i.e. needs to account for row header turned on and off).
Created an attachment (id=51007) Modified files
Unfortunatelly I can not create patches. Will the modified source files do? The modified code is enclosed between "Begin of modification" and "End of modification".

Created an attachment (id=51012) Hotspots screenshot

The second screenshot (hotspot2.png) clearly shows the problem with indexOf in GridItem. It was collected using deep hierarchy (10 levels) and it is the only hotspot. Using lastIndexOf removes the hotspot.

These modifications are not critical to me.

bug.short_desc: Are license files missing of org.mortbay.jetty

long_desc.thetext: In most projects shipped by eclipse that are under the apache license, the license file is contained in a folder called "about_files" at the root of the bundle (see ant or lucene in the SDK). In the case of jetty it is contained in the meta-inf folder. Is this expected?

No it is not expected. Usually, third-party licenses are put in an about_files directory so that all the files will be found when the about.html is viewed from the About dialog (which expands everything from a JAR'ed plug-in that is in the about_files directory).

Fixed in the 5_1_11 branch. I also NL-ed the manifest.mf.
Adrian, I replicated the shape found in other bundles, however this bundle is under APL 1.1, so please confirm that everything is good. Thx.

bug.short_desc: [CheatSheet] Composite cheat sheet XML format typos / enhancements

long_desc.thetext:
In document: /org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/ua_cheatsheet_composite_content.htm
In taskGroup DTD:
#1
<!ELEMENT taskGroup ((task | taskGroup) , intro? , onCompletion? , dependency*)>
should be
<!ELEMENT taskGroup ((task | taskGroup)+ , intro? , onCompletion? , dependency*)>
#2
kind CDATA "set"
should be
kind (set | sequence | choice) "set"
For intro and onCompletion description:
#3
Provide link to FormText javadoc to see allowed tags /org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/api/org/eclipse/ui/forms/widgets /FormText.html
For param description / DTD:
#4
Consider listing all valid parameter name / values in DTD or description. Not sure if this was meant to dynamically allow new parameters in the future for cheatSheetContent extensions. Noticed valid parameter name / values are listed in this document: org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/ua_cheatsheet_composite.htm

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] request for remove(parent, index) API on tree viewer

long_desc.thetext:
3.3
It would be helpful to have a 'remove(Object parent, int index)' method on the tree viewer to complement that 'replace(...)' and 'setChildCount(...)' APIs.
The debug platform requires such a method to implement filtering in virtual tree views. Rather than performing a 'replace/remove' based on elements, the content provider can make one atomic call to remove an element at a specific index.
The remove should be performed while preserving selection, in case the a selected item/element is being removed.
Released >20061016.
Verified using I20061031-0656.

bug.short_desc: Eclipse reports that required library's are missing when in fact they aren't.

long_desc.thetext:
We have a very large code base that includes 19 individual projects. One of these products contains all of the required libraries for both compilation and runtime. This project that contains the libraries is a tomcat projct. The structure of the libraries is:
B2BGateway webapp WEB-INF lib << all the various jar files go here >>
whenever the project is updated to either replace some / all of the above jars, the other projects now show errors that the specific required library is missing and compilation halts.
The ONLY remedy (refreshing the projects does not work) is to remove the jar from the classpath, close the window, and re-add the same jar you just deleted. You do not have to do ANYTHING between the delete and the add. With 19 projects and roughly 30 jars, this is obviously a nightmare. I have also found that by simply modifying the .classpath file (adding a blank line and then removing it) and then saving the file, the compilation error will go away. This tells me there is something in the "history" that might possibly be corrupt. I am not the only one to experience this behavior as others on my team also experience the same issue. This is currently in 3.2 and I have also seen it in 3.1.

Created an attachment (id=50909) Picture of the problem in action!
Here is a graphic showing the problem in action!
Could you pls provide steps to reproduce ? Pls reopen then.
Great, just close the ticket without even an email asking for assistance of any kind. Really shows me how much you wish to address an obvious problem. I tried..

comment 2 is a request for assistance. We need steps to reproduce the failures in order to investigate it. Simply reopen if you have steps to reproduce. If you can only get it inside a big workspace and you can provide the workspace (no problem with proprietary code), then we will find a way to make the transfert.

I have been seeing the same problem in our team. Sometimes you can get the projects to start compiling again by refreshing all projects, but other times even refresh and clean of all projects will not make Eclipse discover the library.
Our setup is similar to the original submitters, with a "commons"-project, which outputs jar-files, which are referenced by the other projects.
I have not yet found any precise way to reproduce the problem, it just seems to occur at random times. I suspect that one possibility is that an updated jar is discovered during the ant build process, when the jar is not yet complete, but this have been hard to reproduce.
Mike, Christian, Looking at your library folder hierarchy that your project is a Web project... Could you confirm this assumption?

Actually we have a full J2EE stack divided into several projects (base/utility, hardware plugins, export/import plugins, EJB, webstart client, web client and so on). I will check with our lead developer if I can send you the entire workspace. It is however proprietary and quite big (around 500 mb), so I don't know if that is the easiest way to go.
I will try to be more vigilant the coming days, and see if I can pinpoint exactly when and why it occurs. Is there any debug log-option I can turn on, so I can send you the log-files and the timestamps of when the problem occured?

I just had the following occur:
* Added a public static final field to a class in our parent base-project. * Recompiled and jar'ed the project using ANT. * Refreshed the base-project. * Tried to use the new field in the child EJB-project, but the editor reported a compilation error. Content-assist could not pick up the new field either. * Control-clicked on the class to get the .class file displayed, and found that it contained the new field. * Saw that the class where I tried to use the new field was not marked as having compile errors in the package explorer.
I realise this is not the exact same problem as the one reported originally in this bug, but it seems to me that it could come from the same problem.
Based on additional users with the same issue, I'm going to re-open. As I have stated before, there is no step 1....4 to re-create. It just kind of shows up from time to time.

yes, ours is basically a webapp. The jars that go into the lib folder of the webapp are build within the workspace via ant. Please look at the picture of the problem in action for the complete project layout as it pertains to my interest.

Mike, Christian,
Looking at your description, it sounds like your problem is similar than this described in bug 161631 => I move your bug to Web Tools component to set it as duplicate...
Thanks for the feedback

Closing as part of mass query to clean up old resolved bugs in untargetted milestones.

bug.short_desc: Remote path for C/C++ Application must be absolute

long_desc.thetext:
When creating the launch configuration for a remote application then the absolute path of the executable on the host machine is the default. I.e. on my windows machine I get a path like d:\workspace\project\Debug\executable which will not work on the (linux) target.
The best idea would be to just give the name of the executable, which would be a relative path to the home directory. I can enter this manually, but when I try to launch then an error dialog pops up saying "Error during file upload", Details "Operation failed. Security violation."
The upload works if I specify a target-absolute path, e.g /home/user/executable It is feasible to enter an absolute path but I had to find this out by trial and error. So at least the error messages should be clearer, but the best would be to
- have the executable without path as default in the "Remote path" text field - and evaluate relative paths in the "Remote path" field as relative to the user's home dir.

Good point.
For a first cut, I'd suggest explicitly stating that only absolute pathes are alloed.
One thing that might be helpful in the future, would be to allow some preference setting for path mappings, such that a local (windows style) path can be mapped to the correct remote path automatically. These mappings could be stored as global Preferences, and on a per-connection basis.

Hi,
My plan was to add a "Browse" button in the future. This would use the file subsystem to allow browsing for a location on the remote. Would this address your concerns?
Thanks.

Sounds like a great idea. You probably know that there are ready-made widgets in RSE for browsing a remote file system. DaveM, could you help Ewa get started?
In the long run, I still think that some kind of mapping would help though - at least to create an initial path to start from in browsing.
There are various ways to provide integration for browsing folders and files in RSE. One example that may help in this case is to use SystemFileWidgetHelpers.createFolderCombo().
Ewa can you add the browse button for entering the remote patch for RSE 1.0.1? The fix would need to be in by December 10th.

Agree. For a first cut, the gdbserver port should be a property of the Launch.
For future enhancement, the port should be stored with the connection, such that it is automatically re-used in multiple launches.

Ewa can you look at this for RSE 1.0.1 ? The fix would need to be in by December 10th.
I'd like to see the gdbserver port be a property of the Launch, with default=2345 This should be possible without API change.
It would be nice if the command used to launch the gdbserver was configurable e.g. some JTAG probe vendors may use different executable names
Created an attachment (id=55380) Patch adding the ability to specify the gdbserver name and the port number. This is done by adding the "remote gdb/mi" debugger with the new "Gdbserver Settings" tab.

I had problems attaching this as a patch...the bugzilla system seems slow.
This patch adds a "Gdbserver Settings" tab under the "Debugger" tab that allows the user to specify the name of gdbserver and the port number.
I'm not too happy with exposing this to the user (although it's good for the time being) because I had to reference some internal cdt classes to make this happen. In the long run this should be stored with the target connection settings.
I, Ewa Matejska, declare that I developed the attached code from scratch, without referencing any 3rd party materials except material licensed under the EPL. I am authorized by my employer to make this contribution under the EPL.

The patch pulls in dependencies to cdt.ui, cdt.debug.ui, and cdt.debug.mi.ui while the previous version of the Launch only did not depend on any CDT UI.
Is there any chance to live without these extra dependencies? At least not using "ControlFactory" should make it possible to live without cdt.ui, which might be important for integrators.
Is there a particular need that the "port" and "gdbserver executable" settings must live in a contributed debugger tab? Could these also live in "normal" controls?
Reopening the bug to avoid people thinking the patch were available while it is not yet checked in.
Created an attachment (id=55442) Removing dependency to org.eclipse.cdt.ui
Created an attachment (id=55443) Screenchot of user experience with the patch.

Hi,
I attached a new patch that removed the dependency on cdt.ui. The dependencies on cdt.debug.ui, and cdt.debug.mi.ui remain. I think these are well worth it for usability purposes (please see the screenshot of what the launch configuration looks like). The gdbserver settings are in the logical place in the Debugger tab. To modify the debugger tab in another way, these dependencies would have to be pulled in as well. Plus, the aim is for this to be temporary and for this to move into the target settings in the future.
I also believe this patch indirectly resolves another problem as well brought up by Hugh O'Keefe recently on the dsdp-tm-dev-bounces mailing list where he had the problem of "The CPU is not supported by selected debugger". This was a result of the cpu options of the debugger we were using ("gdb/mi" which is defined by the CDT). This patch introduces a new debugger ("remote gdb/mi") with the correct cpu options. By adding the new debugger, the cdt.debug.ui dependency would be introduced as well to add the debugger options.
Ewa.

New Patch applied, 148 lines of code. Thanks! Just for completeness, could you please add the Legal message again for the 2nd submission.
questions: * On the debugger / shared libraries tab, the user enters local pathes, not pathes on the remote system. Correct? * The "gdbserver name" could also be an absolute path to a shellscript that performs some setup like setting an LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable etc, correct? - If that's the case I'd like to see a larger editbox for it, and the label changed to "Command to execute gdbserver:" * What's the intended behavior when I open the Launch in Run mode? - I'm surprised that I still see the "debugger" tab, but perhaps that's intentional.
Thanks again!
Mark Fixed.

For the second patch: I, Ewa Matejska, declare that I developed the attached code from scratch, without referencing any 3rd party materials except material licensed under the EPL. I am authorized by my employer to make this contribution under the EPL.
Regarding your questions: >On the debugger / shared libraries tab, the user enters local pathes, not >pathes on the remote system. Correct? Yes local paths. The local gdb needs to have access to local shared libraries.
>The "gdbserver name" could also be an absolute path to a shellscript that > performs some setup like setting an LD_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable etc, > correct? - If that's the case I'd like to see a larger editbox for it, and > the label changed to "Command to execute gdbserver:" No this needs to be gdbserver right now because the code handles launching gdbserver. That is it takes the name in that box and the port number and creates the command to execute to launch gdbserver. The limitation of course is that we're assuming TCP/IP here and we're also assuming that gdbserver needs to be launched. Again, these limitations will be removed when the debug settings are moved into the connection.
> What's the intended behavior when I open the Launch in Run mode? - I'm > surprised that I still see the "debugger" tab, but perhaps that's intentional. This is also how the CDT Launch configurations behave as well although the information in the Debugger tab is not used. So I think it's OK to leave this.
Closing
