bug.short_desc: [hotbug_request] [deployables] IEnterpriseApplication.getModules() doesn't return utility modules

long_desc.thetext: While testing an adopter product on last week's WTP build, I found that the IEnterpriseApplication.getModules() doesn't return entries for loose (i.e. Java project) utility jars within the EAR. This makes it impossible for server adapters to implement Run on Server or publish utility jars correctly. The EAR is correct when exported, so this appears to be an internal problem to this method.
Afetr talking with Tim, I believe this was fixed in WTP 1.5.1 as a part of 156415. I am not able to reproduce on the latest WTP 1.5.1 RC candidate.
Verified, closing.
closed on accident.
putting back into resolved.
verified
Closing.

bug.short_desc: Remote shell remains open from C/C++ remote application launch

long_desc.thetext:
When I start a remote debugging session the session has four processes: - gdbserver debugger - Remote Shell - gdb - executable
After the debugged application terminates the gdbserver, gdb and executable are flagged as terminated as it should be.
The Remote Shell remains alive. It still has a console attached and I can enter commands on it's command line. When I type "exit" the shell exits, but the status is not reflected in the debug view. I have to manually kill the Remote Shell in the debug view. (Works but is ugly)
Leaving a shell connection open is in my opinion pretty bad behavior so for now I'll say that this is a "major" bug.
-----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Testing round 1 installation : eclipse-platform-3.2.0 (M20060629-1905), cdt-3.1.0 RSE install : update-site RSE-complete java.runtime : Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition java.runtime.version=1.5.0_06-b05 os.name: : Windows XP 5.1, Service Pack 2 ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : ssh only targetos : LSB_VERSION="core-2.0-noarch:core-3.0-noarch:core-2.0-ia32:core-3.0-ia32" SUSE LINUX 10.0 (i586) VERSION = 10.0 targetuname : Linux nb14520d 2.6.13-15-smp #1 SMP Tue Sep 13 14:56:15 UTC 2005 i686 i686 i386 GNU/Linux targetvm : java version "1.4.2_06" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_06-b03) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2_06-b03, mixed mode) ------------------------------------------------

Hi,
I've documented this as a limitation in the plugin (org.eclipse.rse.remotecdt/instructions.txt). The problem is that I have no way to detect that the user command in the remote shell has completed. From what I can tell, I can only open a remote shell, and pass commands to it. I cannot just run one command to completion on the remote target.
I can hack it for the debug case to terminate when I detect that the gdb connection has terminated but I have no way to know for the run case that the user program has stopped running.
For now I think this should be marked as a limitation. I will file a bug against the RSE APIs and fix this later when that bug is resolved.
Thanks.

DaveM... I'm wondering whether Ewa could to this: * Start the debuggee with "exec" --> replace the Shell process by the Debuggee * Listen to the Output and Error Streams * If the Streams are closed, the debuggee has terminated
I believe that's how the RSE command view detects that the remote shell has terminated - when user types "exit" the command view is marked as "terminated".
Another option would be to call the debuggee like this: $command ; exit Such that the shell runs the debuggee command, and as soon as the debuggee command is finished, it performs an "exit", leading the output and error streams to close.
Ideas or Comments?
Is "exit" a command that is recognized by every kind of shell subsystem? I can give this method a try very easily.
The "$command ; exit" approach might work. See what happens with that.

All the shells I know of have an "exit" command: Bourne sh, ksh, csh, tcsh, zsh, bash, and cmd.
The only difference is that Unixy flavors of shells use ";" as separator while Windows cmd uses "&" as separator. But there's a method on the IRemoteCmdSubSystem.getCommandSeparator() which returns exactly the separator to use.
Since the "Universal" subsystems that we are dealing with are kind of Unix Flavor anyways, I think we should be OK with the limitation. Moreover, in case a remote shell should not support the "exit" command, the worst thing that can happen is that the shell remains open... which doesnt seem too bad.
I forgot to say that I tried to use the Local connection on a Linux machine. I did not try any real remote connection, as it doesn't even work with Local.

I tried now with a ssh connection to my local machine and this is what I get: The shell executes exit (logout), but the process is still shown as running. If I terminate I get the following log: isActive=true destroy() after exit() isActive=false isActive=false
So the remote shell reports isActive correctly (only Local does it wrong) But even with the "command;exit" workaround the eclipse process does not terminate automatically.
What can I do to get the process terminated one the command exits?

Hi,
I'm attaching a patch for this bug.
I had the same problem where the terminal shell was not exiting with the ssh connection even with the exit command. To fix this I had to modify HostShellAdapter as described in the patch. The problem was the that the waitForExit was not polling the isActive command because of course in the past it would always be active without the exit command. With the patch, the remote shell process. exits when the process exits.
Regarding your problems with the runCommand sometimes being implemented, that's a bug with the RSE API's. It should be filed as a separate bug.
Regarding the exception you're seeing with the Local connection, I've never seen this but I'll give it a try.
Regarding the weird output from the dstore connection, yes please file a bug. I have the same problem with the Remote C/C++ Launcher. At least maybe the implementor can justify why it has to look like that.
Thank You, Ewa
Reopening untim Martin merges the patch.

Thanks Ewa, I'll try it as soon as it get's available.
By the way, would it be possible to move the HostShellAdapter into another rse package? I did copy it into my project, as I don't want a dependency to CDT.
I will open new bugs for the weird output from the dstore connection and the runCommand sometimes being implemented.

Created an attachment (id=52422) Patch to close the Remote Shell process.
Moving Ewa's patch from bug 158788 where it had accidentally been stored to the right bug
Whoops...I had a late night last night. Thanks for catching that Martin.

(In reply to comment #13) > By the way, would it be possible to move the HostShellAdapter into another rse > package? I did copy it into my project, as I don't want a dependency to CDT.
Applied the patch, it should be in RSE 1.0 RC2. Marking this bug fixed, since the other observations are tracked separately:
Bug 161770 (runCommand fails with ssh) Bug 161773 (strange output with dstore) Bug 161777 (move HostShellOutputAdapter)

I can confirm that the fix works for SSH, Windows dstore in RSE 1.0RC2. Local still fails, due to the isActive problem described in comment 7. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=158786#c7
I'm going to open a seperate bug for that problem.

Thanks.
If you verify a bug, feel free to set status "VERIFIED". This helps us to know that a user (reporter) actually verified it. We will then set it CLOSED once we've verified it as well.
Closing.

attachment.desc: Patch to close the Remote Shell process.

bug.short_desc: external browser can't be found on Redhat

long_desc.thetext:
Ciao :) Following situation: - RHEL4, U3: start eclipse - SWT style welcome shows up, but the css one should for linux! - Window->Preferences->General->Web Browser shows: "Default system Web browser" as only option for an external browser, internal browser is disabled. - An Error Log has been generated in the mean time: Internal browser is not available: No more handles [Unknown Mozilla path (MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME not set)] - Back in the preferences, if I click on the "Default system Web browser" to show me it's settings I get a NPE(see bottom) - Links from the welcome page into the web work just fine, i.e. they open firefox as browser and walk it to the link.
Now, my system, Red Hat Enterprise Workstation 4, Update 3, is special, there is no mozilla installed. Firefox is also installed in a custom way, by linking the executable, firefox, into /usr/bin. It points to /opt/firefox/firefox. Now, I tried to set MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME to /opt/firefox to help Eclipse a bit, that's when the following error happened: Internal browser is not available: No more handles [NS_InitEmbedding /opt/firefox/ error -2147221164]
Eclipse should: 1.) handle the error situation in a better way(more descriptive error msgs), 2.) use the /usr/bin/firefox link as external browser without the need to have firefox installed in /etc/gre.d or pointed to by MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME 3.) use my firefox (1.5.0.7) or tell me why it can't
Please feel free to ask for more info if you need any..
NPE: java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.ui.internal.browser.BrowserDescriptorDialog.createDialogArea(BrowserDescriptorDialog.java:104) at org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.Dialog.createContents(Dialog.java:802) at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.create(Window.java:426) at org.eclipse.jface.dialogs.Dialog.create(Dialog.java:1124) at org.eclipse.jface.window.Window.open(Window.java:785) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.browser.WebBrowserPreferencePage$3.doubleClick(WebBrowserPreferencePage.java:276) at org.eclipse.jface.viewers.StructuredViewer$1.run(StructuredViewer.java:796)
Upon retrying to set "MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME" to a valid firefox I also saw this error several times: Internal browser is not available: XPCOM error -2147221164

Firefox can only be used if it's dynamically linked, which will not be the case unless it either came shipped with your linux or you built it from source.
Which of the following directories do you have in your /usr/lib? *mozilla* *firefox* *xulrunner* *seamonkey*
For more info on using the browser on linux see http://www.eclipse.org/swt/faq.php#browserlinux .

There is two levels of problems here: 1.) My firefox can't be used 2.) The error handling of "1.)" is bad: - the preference page for web-browsers produces a NullPointerException - the swt intro is used without an indication why - no error log intro whatsoever is displayed 3.) The preference page can't display the usable external browser firefox although it is successfully used for help and external links in the intro.
as for the first problem, the firefox on my system might be dynamically linked( a "ldd /opt/firefox/firefox-bin" shows a LOT of dlls it depends on) but there are not many files in /usr/lib: /usr/lib/mozilla-1.7.3 /usr/lib/mozilla-1.7.3/libnssckbi.so /usr/lib/mozilla /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins/nphelix.so /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins/nphelix.xpt /usr/lib/firefox-1.0 /usr/lib/firefox-1.0/chrome /usr/lib/firefox-1.0/chrome/installed-chrome.txt /usr/lib/firefox-1.0/defaults.ini
I know, the correct installation of firefox on linux is hardly a problem of the eclipse community but the real issue here is that the unusable firefox is not reported as such, it's rather used partly and fails silently in other parts...

re: the preference page NullPointerException I'm not able to reproduce this, but if you have steps that NPE reliably then you should log a new bug report with Platform - UI.
re: non-Browser intro page / empty error log True, the alternate intro page is used without explaination. Maybe something should be logged? (Though there are platforms like Solaris that don't have a Browser implementation, so its log would fill up with these in the normal use case).
ldd'ing my statically-linked firefox install gives a long list of libraries too. If your firefox install has a <firefoxRoot>/components/libwidget_gtk2.so file then it's dynamically linked, otherwise it's not.
Moving report to UI to consider giving more notice (eg.- logging a warning) the first time that it fails to instantiate a Browser. I believe that core does this if it's running on a platform for which its file access natives are not found.

(I should have checked this first) Actually a warning message like this is logged to the error log. Taking this bug back to update the error that is thrown from the Browser and subsequently displayed in the error log.

fixed > 0929
I've updated the error that's thrown in your scenario on linux-gtk and linux-motif. Its text now has a sentence indicating that MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME may not be pointing at an embeddable GRE.

Thanks for the work so far. I reopened the bug because I still see the NPE happening, even in a fully mozilla- equipped environment. The problem is IMHO the possibility to double-click the node "Default system Web Browser", the "Edit" button at least is not enabled for that node, while it is for the one below: "Mozilla". This appears to be a more general bug with that default node on linux.
Some info on the system: I have mozilla installed, the css implementation of the intro is used and external links are opened with "Mozilla 1.4.3".
ok, I now see the NPE that you previously mentioned. I've logged new bug 159468 to track this. Marking this report as fixed.

bug.short_desc: Add accessible image

long_desc.thetext:
The standard native widgets on Linux (RHEL 5 or FC5) that include an image already expose the Image interface with default values. (See http://developer.gnome.org/doc/API/2.0/atk/AtkImage.html.) But custom widget authors (including Draw2d and GMF authors) need a mechanism to expose images in their custom widgets to native assistive technologies (like a screen reader).
I suggest adding a new AccessibleImageListener to the org.eclipse.swt.accessibility package to allow custom widget authors the ability to expose the rich AtkImage interface. Also, SWT widgets that include an image should allow customization of the image information through this new interface.
The mechanism to implement this functionality on Windows will be added soon.

bug.short_desc: [EditPart] Extend IAdaptable parser context to provide adapters to gef-specific notions.

long_desc.thetext:
Actually default org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.editpolicies.LabelDirectEditPolicy uses an instance of EObjectAdapterEx to pass the context to the instaneof IParser.
This Adapter extends default EObjectAdpater with ability to adapt to notation element. It would be very helpful if this Adpater would be adaptible to some class that belong to GEF domain, say to the IGraphicalEditPart.class or EditPolicy.class or even DiagramEditor.class.
One of the use cases that require IGraphicalEditPart adapter is creation of the "misses" elements that are referenced by the parsed user text on the fly. Say, if user writes "a : A" in the property inplace editor, it would be nice to create, say the class A to type this property. To achieve this we need GEF domain notions available.
Moving to the next release, GMF 2.1.

bug.short_desc: MessageBox blocks display thread on linux

long_desc.thetext:
Created an attachment (id=53870) Patch for 158796
Here's a patch that will fix this behavior on GTK. Messagebox and all other callers of gtk_dialog_run (ie. ColorDialog, DirectoryDialog, FileDialog, FontDialog, PrintDialog) will now run the asyncMessage loop when the main loop has some cycles to spare.
I added 2 new methods to the OS class :
guint g_idle_add (GSourceFunc function,pointer data); gboolean g_source_remove (guint tag);
so the natives will need to be regenerated. (I also included the org.eclipse.swt.internal.gtk.OS.properties file from the generation tool in the patch).
I have verified that the async update behavior is the same on: - Win32 - GTK (with this patch) - Motif
On Mac, only the Font Dialog updates properly.
Silenio, can you release this patch? Thanks!
Changes reviewed - patch released. Thanks Silenio!

bug.short_desc: FileDialog limit on multi-select

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, an Open, Multi-select FileDialog allows me to select 1000+ files, but does not return success, so I cannot get the list of files that were selected.
This seems to be caused by the size of the buffer created for the file list. Is there a way of removing this limitation for very large directories of files?

Right now the limit is 32K. I can increase it. When the buffer overflows, Windows returns FNERR_BUFFERTOOSMALL and the call fails. I could grow the buffer and reopen the dialog. Suggestions?
We need to determine what other Windows applications do ...
... never mind, found it!

bug.short_desc: Compare editor's saved state is not in sync with normal file

long_desc.thetext:

While the contents of a normal editor is now in sync with the left side of the compare editor (e.g. when compare is opened via Synchronize view) the editor's saved state is not in sync. This is pretty bad because when you switch to either of the yet dirty editors you get asked whether to load the data from disc, or a message appears telling that the file has changed on the file system.
I've played around a bit and have not been able to get the prompt you mentijon. Could you provide a set of steps that reproduce the problem?

Stesp provided in bug 159518.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 159518 ***

bug.short_desc: No types being found when doing codeassist

long_desc.thetext:
I20060921-1252 (jdt.core v_713) I have a workspace in which any attempt to use the code assist results in an empty list of proposition. This happen for my types as well as types defined in the JRE.
Let me know where you want me to give you the workspace.

David, I'll give you the workspace to reproduce it. We tried to use the .options file to debug completion activities and we could see that the completion engine is triggered, but no completion is returned.

There is no proposal in this workspace because Java completion is disabled. The preferences 'Java>Editor>Content Assist>Advanced>Type Proposals' and 'Java>Editor>Content Assist>Advanced>Other Java Proposals' are disabled.
I don't find something about preferences in .log file. Did you change yourself these preferences ?
I never changed those preferences. I did not even know there were such preferences. However I may have used this workspace with 3.1 and 3.2 back and forth.

I tried to reproduce the problem with a new workspase. I opened the same workspace with 3.1 and 3.2 several times. I exported and imported preferences several times. But i am unable to reproduce the problem.
As the problem seems to be in the preferences area, then i move this bug to JDT/Text

Pascal, did you eventually had Mylar in one of your installs? This could have caused this behavior as noted in the 3.2 README.
Not much we can do here.
I was using a plain SDK.
>However I may have used this workspace with 3.1 and 3.2 back and forth. This is not supported.

bug.short_desc: TPTP Article on using the JUnit Test Case.

long_desc.thetext:
A simple article on how to use and work with the TPTP JUnit Test case. This would be the first article in a series of articles on using various TPTP functions. We start with the TPTP JUnit Test case and progress into more complex test suites, profiling, probing techniques and finally touch upon a simple Performance test. A simple 2 thread application will be used for all the tutorials.
Table of Contents: 1. Introduction Required software and plug-ins.
2. Design Breif overview of the example application.
3. Construction Brief overview of the primary classes.
4. Project Preparation Setup some folders, logging, etc...
5. TPTP JUnit Tests Meat of the article. Provides a step-by-step approach to creating a TPTP JUnit Test for one Java class in the example application...plenty of screen shots for clarity. Step through a basic test and review the Test Execution files and how to review the results. Also, discuss the subtle differences in the TPTP Test Editor with regards to editing the Behaviors...i.e. whether using the test editor or the code editor.
6. Excercise Step through a second JUnit Test using less screen shots and more discussion. In this one, the TPTP Test will use the code editor to work through the behaviors.
7. Synopsis Review the high points and segway to the next tutorial in the series.
This article is already in it's first draft form and is probably ready for review. It's a bit lengthy because of the screen shots.
thx,
adym
+1 Sounds good to me.

Created an attachment (id=52717) First draft and eclipse projects.
Here is the first draft of the TPTP JUnit Tutorial. I had to remove the log4j.jar, xerces.jar and jdom.jar libs in order to get the zipfile under 2MB. The zipfile has the following eclipse projects in it: - tptp-tutorial-junit - Contains the docs/article. - tptp-tutorial-problem-001 - Contains source but no solution files. - tptp-tutorial-solution-001 - Contains source and solution files.
The article is lengthy due to the number of TPTP screen shots. The hope is that the first article will be lengthy, but other articles in the series won't include as many screen shots...aka the reader should have worked thru the original article before moving into the others. I tried using the docbook route, but never got the Orangevolt plug-in to work.
Anyway, let me know what to edit, how, etc...
tia,
adym

Good start. Some comments:
You should clip out the bits of the template document at the bottom.
I think that the tutorial would benefit from a brief discussion on the topic if why the TPTP JUnit stuff is better than plain old JUnit.
The screenshots look terrible. They're grainy. I hate to ask you to redo them, so I'll leave it to you to decide how important it is.
At the very start, there is a bullet: "Start by downloading one of the TPTP JUnit projects." There is no link. Also, more direct instructions might be better; e.g. "Download project x". The "Start Eclipse and point it to the parent folder where you unzipped the TPTP JUnit project files. " statement may be difficult for folks who are new to Eclipse to process (and even seasoned people). Do you mean point as in point the import wizard, or as the workspace?
I think you need to revisit these initial steps.
I don't like the steady use of bullets throughout the tutorial. Bullets should be used to describe the steps concisely, followed by proper paragraphs providing detail. Also, it wouldn't hurt to break the document down into sections with titles like "Setup", "Building the Tests", "Running the Tests", "Analysing the Results", etc.
I'm marking this bug as LATER due to apparent inactivity. Please feel free to reopen.
